arguments.argument: Large donations give wealthy individuals undue political influence.
Money in politics creates corruption and special interest control.
Stricter limits would level the playing field for all candidates.
It would reduce the influence of corporate donations in elections.
Public funding of elections could be more effective than private donations.
Limiting donations would force candidates to engage more with voters.
The current system favors incumbents with large donor networks.
Campaign finance reform is necessary to restore public trust.
It would prevent billionaires from single-handedly funding campaigns.
Strict limits would reduce negative campaigning and excessive political ads.
Campaign donations are a form of free speech protected by the First Amendment.
Stricter limits would disadvantage underfunded candidates.
Political campaigns require significant funding to reach voters.
Donors should have the right to support candidates they believe in.
Regulating donations could lead to legal loopholes and dark money sources.
Public financing of campaigns could increase taxpayer burden.
Donations enable grassroots candidates to compete with established politicians.
Enforcing stricter limits would be difficult and costly.
Candidates might turn to less transparent fundraising methods.
Transparency in donations is more important than strict limits.
